Graphical abstract Highlights ► S-TiO2(x) has been synthesized by sol–gel method. ► V2O5/S-TiO2(x) has been synthesized by wet impregnation method. ► The addition of V2O5 to S-TiO2 has enhanced the visible-light absorption. ► The migration of charge carriers in V2O5/S-TiO2 increased the activity. ► The stability of the nanocomposites has been revealed from the fluorescence study. Diverse approaches are being made in search of a visible-light active TiO2 photocatalysts. In this study, S-TiO2(x) nanocatalysts with x =2, 4 and 6 (x =S/Ti molar ratio) were synthesized by sol–gel method and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites by wet impregnation method using ammonium metavanadate as a source of vanadium. The synthesized catalysts were characterized by diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, N2 adsorption desorption studies, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and high resolution transmission electron microscopy techniques. The photogenerated reactive species OH radical estimated from photoluminescence spectra was directly correlated to the visible-light absorption of the catalyst. The photocatalytic activities of all the synthesized catalysts were evaluated for the degradation of MB under visible light irradiation. The excellent stability of V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites has been revealed from the linear relationship between the fluorescence intensity and the time. The addition of sulfur and V2O5 to TiO2 has significantly enhanced the visible-light photocatalytic activity by modifying the optical and electronic properties of TiO2. The enhanced visible-light photocatalytic activity has been attributed to the efficient visible-light absorption of V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites and efficient charge separation due to migration of charge carriers between S-TiO2 and V2O5. Keywords Nanotitania Sulfur Vanadia Nanocomposites Visible-light absorption Photocatalytic activity 1 Introduction One of the most persistent problems affecting people throughout the world is inadequate access to clean water and sanitation. Problems with water are expected to grow worse in the coming decades, with water scarcity occurring globally, even in regions currently considered water-rich. As a potential solution to the recent severe problems of environment crises, destruction of organic and inorganic pollutants on semiconductor photocatalysts has been extensively studied [1–4]. Honda and Fujishima in 1972 reported titanium dioxide (TiO2) as an efficient photocatalyst, which has received much attention till now due to its advantages of being inexpensive, non-toxic, and a good photostable semiconductor [5]. However, the wide band gap energy (E g – 3.2eV, λ – 385nm) of anatase TiO2 can create electron–hole pairs on irradiation with UV-light to initiate photocatalytic processes, and thus only ∼5% of the solar spectrum can be utilized. Hence, for useful utilization of the solar energy numerous attempts have been made to develop a photocatalyst that efficiently absorbs visible light, which occupies the main part of the solar spectrum and also to reduce the recombination rate of the photogenerated electron–hole pairs. Now, there are several approaches that are known to improve the photocatalytic activity of TiO2 materials under visible light irradiation. Many attempts have been made to prepare visible light driven photocatalysts by doping TiO2 with transition metals (Pt, Fe, Mo, Ru, V, etc.) [6–8], dye-sensitization [9], surface modification [10,11], and coupling with narrow band gap semiconductor [12,13]. It must be noted, however, that each of these methods has some drawbacks such as thermal instability and electron–hole recombination. To overcome these drawbacks, non-metal ions as a dopant have been employed as an alternative approach for the formation of visible light active TiO2 photocatalysts. Theoretical calculation has revealed that band-gap narrowing originates from the electronic perturbations caused by the change of lattice parameters and/or by the presence of the trap states within conduction and valence bands of TiO2 [14,15]. Recently several research groups have demonstrated that non-metal doping such as boron [16], nitrogen [17,18], carbon [19,20], fluorine [21], sulfur [14,22–24] and iodine [25,26] can efficiently modify the electronic structure and narrow down the band gap energy of TiO2 to achieve visible-light photocatalytic activity. However, the visible light absorption of the non-metal doped TiO2 other than nitrogen and sulfur in the visible region are relatively small. It is also interesting to note that sulfur, unlike other non-metal dopants, may exist in more than one oxidation state (S2−, S4+ or S6+) in TiO2 depending on the synthetic conditions or the types of sulfur precursor. The enhanced photocatalytic activity has been shown regardless of the sulfur oxidation state [14,24]. The utility of the sulfur doped TiO2 over a broadly used Aeroxide P25 catalyst will be focused when extension of the absorption spectrum into the visible-region is more important than the efficient use of UV photons. It has recently been reported that a considerable enhancement in the photocatalytic efficiency of TiO2 under visible light has been obtained by coupling with low band gap semiconductors such as CdS, CdSe, Ag2S and V2O5 [13]. An extensive literature review has also shown many possibilities of improving the efficiency of photodegradation over titania by manipulating the TiO2 structures at nanoscale, which can be easily obtained by sol–gel method. The sol–gel method facilitates the preparation of the photocatalyst in the form of powders as well as coatings. Moreover, it is very convenient to produce nanocatalytic materials in which different phases could be highly dispersed in an inorganic matrix. As an important transition metal-oxide semiconductor, V2O5 having relatively low band gap energy (about 2.3eV) capable of absorbing a broad solar spectrum [27], is a subject of intensive study because of its unique physical and chemical properties. V2O5 is the most stable form in the vanadium oxide family, which allow a wide range of practical applications such as electrochromic devices, cathodic electrodes for lithium batteries, gas sensors and so on [28,29]. Among its interesting properties and possible applications, the photocatalytic action of V2O5 makes it a promising candidate for the degradation of organic pollutants such as hydrocarbons. Fei et al. synthesized hollow V2O5 microspheres by solvo-thermal route, exhibiting excellent photoactivity for degradation of rhodamine B (RhB) under UV light [30]. Hence, the loading of metal oxide like V2O5 onto other photocatalyst has been studied as it is proved to enhance the photocatalytic activity due to promoted separation of charge carrier [31,32]. This makes V2O5/TiO2 system an effective catalytic material for photocatalytic application. In particular, V2O5 supported on TiO2, increases the selectivity of the oxidation of o-xylene to phthalic anhydride and also, found to be a promising catalyst for the reduction of NO x with NH3 [33]. Multiple layered semiconductor systems like V2O5/SmVO4 have also been prepared and used for photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue [34]. Recently, Wang et al. [35] synthesized V2O5/TiO2 nanoheterostructures by electrospinning and reported an increase in the rate of photocatalytic degradation of Rhodamine B under visible-light irradiation. Martha et al. [36] have also succeeded in the fabrication of V2O5/N,S-TiO2 composite by solid state reaction route. They reported the enhanced activity toward hydrogen production (296.6μmolh−1) under visible light and successive phenol degradation under direct solar light irradiation. They concluded that the heterostructured nanocomposites bring a new insight into the designing of highly efficient photocatalysts for organic compounds and potential technological applications. Hence, in the search of visible-light active TiO2 photocatalysts, an attempt has been made to synthesize a series of S-TiO2(x) nanocatalysts by sol–gel method and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites by wet impregnation method. To the best of our knowledge, there has been no report on the synthesis and visible-light photocatalytic application of V2O5/S-TiO2 photocatalyst system. In this study, attempts have been made to modify the optical and electronic properties of TiO2 using sulfur and vanadium. The structural properties of all the catalysts were studied using Diffuse reflectance UV–visible (DRUV–vis) spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), Raman spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), N2 adsorption desorption studies and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) techniques. The photocatalytic activities of the synthesized catalysts were evaluated for the degradation of methylene blue under visible light irradiation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of photocatalysts Titanium tetraisopropoxide (Alfa Aesar, 95%), absolute ethanol (Hayman Limited, 99.9%), thiourea (SRL, 99%), ammonium metavanadate (Sigma–Aldrich, 99%), terephthalic acid (SRL, 98%), sodium hydroxide (Merck, 98%) and methylene blue (Plazo Laboratories Pvt. Ltd.) were used without further purification. Titanium dioxide Aeroxide P25 (anatase/rutile in the percentage of 80/20, specific surface area 50m2 g−1) was utilized as provided. Deionized water was used throughout this study. 2.1.1 Preparation of S-TiO2 nanocatalysts S-TiO2(x) nanocatalysts with different S/Ti molar ratios (2, 4 and 6) were prepared by slightly modified sol–gel method [14,35] as follows: Titanium tetraisopropoxide (TTIP) was dissolved in 20mL of ethanol and hydrolyzed using 50mL of H2O:ethanol (1:1) mixture. The pH of the mixture was maintained at 3.0 using 0.2M H2SO4 to form a gel. Aqueous thiourea (TU) solution was added dropwise to the above gel with constant stirring and further sonicated for 30min at room temperature. The white precipitate obtained was filtered, washed several times with water in order to remove the sulfate and dried overnight in an oven at 330K. The dried powder was further calcined at 773K for 3h to obtain sulfur-doped TiO2. The S/Ti molar ratio corresponds to 2:1, 4:1 and 6:1, and the resulting catalyst is designated as S-TiO2(2), S-TiO2(4) and S-TiO2(6) respectively. The pure TiO2 was prepared following the same procedure in the absence of thiourea and it is denoted as TiO2. 2.1.2 Preparation of V2O5/S-TiO2 nanocomposites The V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites were synthesized by wet impregnation method. The calculated amount of ammonium metavanadate (3wt.% of V2O5) is dissolved in water under ultrasonication and then impregnated to the above synthesized S-TiO2(x) nanocatalysts. Further, it was dried at 330K and calcined at 773K for 4h to obtain the V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites. For reference, the pure V2O5 material was prepared by thermal decomposition of ammonium metavanadate at 773K for 4h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The physico-chemical characteristics of all the catalysts were studied using the following measurements. The optical properties of the samples were determined from DRUV–vis spectra using Shimadzu UV2450 spectrophotometer with BaSO4 as the reference in the range of 190–800nm. The band gap energy of the samples was determined by using the equation: E g =1240/λ where, λ is the wavelength of the absorption edge [37]. The fluorescence spectra were recorded on PerkinElmer LS-45 model using Xenon lamp as the excitation source with 10nm slit width and photomultiplier tube as the detector. The XRD patterns of all the samples were recorded on X-ray diffractometer (Phillips X’pert model) using Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.1548nm) for 20–70° (2θ) at a step scan rate of 0.02° θ s−1 to identify the phase constitutions in samples and to determine their crystallite size. The average crystallite size (〈D〉) of the synthesized catalysts is calculated by applying the Scherrer's equation: 〈D〉= kλ/β cos θ, where k (0.94) is the Scherrer constant, λ is the X-ray wavelength (0.1548nm), β the full-width at half-maximum of crystal plane (101) and θ the diffraction angle of the crystal plane (101). The lattice parameters were measured using (101) and (200) crystal planes by using the equation: 1/d 2 = h 2/a 2 + k 2/b 2 + l 2/c 2, where, d (hkl) is the distance between crystal planes, hkl is the crystal index and a, b and c are lattice parameters (in anatase form, a = b ≠ c) [38]. HRTEM and bright field images were recorded using a Jeol JEM-2100F TEM instrument operated at 200kV and an energy dispersive X-ray instrument (EDX). The specimens were prepared by dipping a holey carbon-coated copper grid into the dilute suspension. The materials were ground gently and dispersed ultrasonically in water, and several drops of the suspension were deposited onto the grid. N2 adsorption desorption isotherms were obtained at 77K on a Belsorp mini, BEL Japan system. Prior to analysis, the samples were pretreated at 473K for 2h under nitrogen atmosphere. The average particle size (L) of the samples was calculated from the formula: L =(6×103)/(SA×density), where SA is the specific surface area [39]. Raman spectra were recorded on Bruker RFS27 operating with 1064nm line of Nd:YAG Laser source in rock solid interferometer in the range of 100–700cm−1 using liquid nitrogen cooled germanium detector with the resolution of 4cm−1. The FTIR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer FTIR spectrophotometer using KBr pellet technique. About 10mg of the sample was ground with about 70mg of spectral grade KBr and made into a pellet using a hydraulic press. The pellet was scanned at 4cm−1 resolution in the range of 4000–400cm−1. XPS spectra were acquired using M/s. Omicron Nanotechnology (GmBH, Germany) with XM1000 monochromatic Al Kα source (hυ =1486.6eV) operated at 300W (20mA and 15kV) and a hemispherical electron energy analyzer. Data acquisition and manipulation were carried out using manufacturer supplied CasaXPS software. During acquisition of spectra the pressure in the chamber was maintained at 3.5E-10mbar to ensure a clean surface. Charge neutralizer (CN101) has been used for surface charge neutralization to determine the chemical state and to quantify the dopant concentration. All the binding energies were referenced to the C 1s line at 284.6eV for calibration. The chemical analysis was performed to determine the amount of dopants added. The S was estimated by the elemental analysis using Elementar Vario EL III. The weight percentage of V2O5 was estimated using inductively coupled plasma–optical emission spectroscopy (ICP–OES), PerkinElmer Optima 5300 DV equipped with concentric nebulizer and cyclonic spray chamber. 2.3 Photocatalytic reactor set-up The visible-light photocatalytic efficiency of S-TiO2(x) and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) catalysts were evaluated for degradation of methylene blue (MB) aqueous solution. Photocatalytic degradation was performed in a home-made slurry batch visible-light photoreactor. A 500W tungsten lamp built into a housing with polished anodized aluminum reflectors was used as the visible-light source and placed 6cm away from the reactor tube. The lamp emits radiation predominantly in the visible region at a wavelength above 410nm with an intensity of 20mW/cm2. About 100mL of 30ppm MB solution with 0.1g of catalyst was taken in a glass tube and oxygen was bubbled into the solution throughout the experiment. 2.3.1 Product analysis An aliquot of 10mL of sample was collected at particular time interval and the catalyst was separated by centrifugation and filtration, through Millipore filters (0.45μm diameter) of the suspension. The photocatalytic activities were evaluated by detecting MB in the wavelength of 664nm using UV-Visible spectrophotometer. The kinetics of photocatalytic reactions can be described as pseudo first order where C 0 and C t are the initial concentration of MB and final concentration of MB at time “t”, respectively and the rate constants (k, min−1) determined from plots of ln(C 0/C t ) versus irradiation time [38]. The filtered samples were also analyzed using Shimadzu Total Organic Carbon Analyzer (V CPN) with Non-Dispersive Infra-Red detector (NDIR) to determine the amount of Total Organic Carbon (TOC). 2.3.2 MB adsorption studies The MB adsorption studies have been performed as reported in literature [19]. About 0.02g of the catalysts was added to 20mL of MB (20mg/L) aqueous solution separately in the dark. The solution was kept in stirred condition to have uniform concentration throughout the samples. All the experiments were carried out under identical condition with utmost care to minimize the error. The initial and equilibrium concentrations were determined using the UV–vis spectrophotometer. The amounts of MB adsorbed were calculated as follows: n (ads) = V ×ΔC, where n (ads) is the number of moles of MB adsorbed; V is the volume (20ml) of MB solution and ΔC is the difference between the initial concentration (C 0) and equilibrium concentration (C e). 2.3.3 Determination of OH radicals The analysis of OH radical formed on the sample surface under visible light irradiation was performed by fluorescence technique using terephthalic acid, which readily reacted with OH radicals to produce highly fluorescent 2-hydroxyterephthalic acid. The intensity of the peak attributed to 2-hydroxyterephthalic acid was known to be proportional to the amount of OH radicals formed. Five milligram of photocatalyst was suspended in to 80mL of aqueous solution containing 0.01M NaOH and 3mM terephthalic acid. Before exposure to light irradiation, the suspension was stirred in dark for 30min. Then, 5mL of the solution was taken out after each desirable time and filtered using 0.45μm membrane filter. The solution was analyzed in the fluorescence spectrophotometer; 2-hydroxyterephthalic acid gives a peak at a wavelength of about 425nm by the excitation with the wavelength of 315nm [40]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization Fig. 1 shows the DRUV–vis absorption spectra of TiO2, S-TiO2(x), V2O5 and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) catalysts. The first derivative spectra are shown in the inset of the figure. Compared to the spectrum of pure TiO2, a shift to the lower energy region and absorption shoulder was clearly observed for S-TiO2(2) (Fig. 1a). The observed shift in absorption maximum and absorption edges are due to the p-states of sulfur atom contributing to band gap narrowing by mixing with O 2p states. The sulfur modified TiO2 shows two absorption edges around 410 and 550nm. The first absorption edge at 410nm for the first absorption band around 390–420nm is due to TiO2 fundamental band transitions and the second absorption edge at 550nm for the second absorption band around 420–590nm is due to sulfur doping [23]. The wide and strong absorption in the range greater than 550nm shows the presence of TiO2−x low-valence compound [41]. S-TiO2(4) and S-TiO2(6) also shows two transitions with red shift in absorption compare to S-TiO2(2). However, the absorption band of S-TiO2(4) and S-TiO2(6) was found to be the same irrespective of the amount of sulfur doped. The two absorption bands confirm the presence of two different surface states characteristics of pure and sulfur doped TiO2. UV–vis absorbance spectra of V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites are shown in Fig. 1b, in which the bands attributable to the band gap transition of TiO2 as well as the bands attributable to supported vanadium species are clearly seen. The bands in the region 340–365nm are attributable to polymeric vanadium (V5+) species with VO4, or possibly isolated vanadium species VO6 (V5+) with physically adsorbed water molecules. The absorption of V5+ cation due to d–d charge transition observed around 400–600nm confirms the presence of V2O5 species [42]. Compared with the spectrum of S-TiO2(x), V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites showed an intense shift of optical absorption shoulders and the absorption edges to the visible region. A wide absorption of light with the wavelength longer than 420nm clearly observed in the first derivative spectra (Fig. 1a (inset)), contributes to the visible light sensitization of the S-TiO2(x) catalysts. In particular, the second absorption band observed around 420–590nm for S-TiO2(x) catalysts further shifts to the lower energy visible region by the addition of V2O5. The tailing of absorption curves of V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites is found to be different from the pure V2O5. The differential spectrum of V2O5/S-TiO2(x) shows a band at 280 and 340nm due to the presence of tetrahedrally co-ordinated V5+ ions. On the other hand, a weak broad band around 600–800nm observed for V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites is attributed to the polymeric vanadium oxide species formed on the surface of the TiO2 [42]. It is also worth noting, that the second absorption band around 420–550nm of S-TiO2(x) get mixed up with the first absorption band observed around 390–420nm (Fig. 1a and b (inset)), suggesting the lowering of band gap energy by the addition of V2O5 species and thereby favors the enhanced visible light absorption. The optical band gap energies of the catalysts were determined from Tauc Plot and the values are listed in Table 1 . The crystal structure and phase composition of the synthesized TiO2, S-TiO2(x), V2O5 and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) catalysts were confirmed by the XRD patterns and are shown in Fig. 2 . Additionally, the Aeroxide P25 was also examined by XRD for comparison (results are not shown). The polycrystalline anatase structure was confirmed by the presence of (101), (004), (200), (105) and (211) diffraction peaks (JCPDS 21-1272). The average crystallite size calculated using the Scherrer's equation from (101) crystal plane of anatase phase are 31.6, 15.6, 14.2, 16.2, 35.2, 32.6 and 32.7nm for TiO2, S-TiO2(2), S-TiO2(4), S-TiO2(6), V2O5/TiO2, V2O5/S-TiO2(2) and V2O5/S-TiO2(4), respectively. The diffraction peak intensity of S-TiO2(x) catalyst (Fig. 2a) is weaker than that of TiO2 and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) catalysts (Fig. 2b). This implies that the crystallite size of S-TiO2(x) catalysts is smaller than that of the TiO2 and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) catalysts; this contraction may be due to the addition of S dopant into the TiO2 lattice. It is also worth noting that the crystallinity decreases with increase in sulfur content. Further, the diffraction peaks corresponding to only anatase TiO2 were observed in all the catalysts and no characteristic diffraction peak corresponding to orthorhombic V2O5 (JCPDS 72-0433) species was observed. This observation shows the fine dispersion of V2O5 on S-TiO2 surface. However, the modified TiO2 catalysts showed broader (101) peak than that of the pure TiO2 suggesting that the lattice structure of TiO2 was locally distorted by the added dopants [38]. The tetragonal Bravais lattice type was verified by the values of lattice parameters ‘a’ and ‘c’, calculated from the two diffraction planes (101) and (004) (Table 1). TEM, HRTEM images and SAED patterns of TiO2, S-TiO2(4), V2O5/TiO2 and V2O5/S-TiO2(4) catalysts were recorded and shown in Fig. 3 . The spherical particles with an average particle size of 19, 14, 28 and 30nm were seen from the TEM images. These values are consistent with the typical crystallite sizes calculated from XRD results. It is also observed that the primary particles of V2O5/TiO2 and V2O5/S-TiO2(4) composites appear to have merged together and found to be irregular, thus accounting for the decrease in surface area (Table 1). The inset shown in Fig. 3a confirms the fine dispersion of V2O5 on the surface of TiO2 and S-TiO2(4) in V2O5/TiO2 and V2O5/S-TiO2(4) catalysts. The average particle sizes of V2O5 on the surface of TiO2 and S-TiO2(4) are 2.6nm and 2.3nm, respectively. Hence, the reflections corresponding to V2O5 were not observed in the XRD patterns (Fig. 2). This further supports the formation of real nanocomposites and it is reflected in the enhancement of visible-light absorption as observed from DRUV–vis results (Fig. 1). The well resolved lattice fringes observed in Fig. 3b reveals the crystalline nature of the samples. The measured fringes of 3.5Å matches well with the distance of (101) crystal planes of anatase in TiO2, S-TiO2(4), V2O5/TiO2 and V2O5/S-TiO2(4) catalysts [36]. The formation of orthorhombic V2O5 on the surface of TiO2 and S-TiO2(4) in V2O5/TiO2 and V2O5/S-TiO2(4) catalysts is confirmed from the measured fringes of 4.36Å, matches well with the distance of (010) crystal planes of V2O5 [36]. The corresponding SAED patterns shown as an inset (Fig. 3b) display ring patterns, which can be indexed to the tetragonal phase of anatase TiO2 indicating its polycrystalline nature. The poor crystalline nature of TiO2 due to the growth of V2O5 on the surface of TiO2 and S-TiO2(4) in V2O5/TiO2 and V2O5/S-TiO2(4) catalysts are clearly reflected in the SAED patterns. The brightest central spot in SAED is blocked in order to get a better contrast. Raman spectroscopy is a very powerful tool for detecting the different crystalline phases in TiO2 and the change in surface structure due to doping. Raman spectra of TiO2, S-TiO2(x), V2O5 and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) catalysts are presented in Fig. 4 . Bulk anatase has a tetragonal structure (space group I41/amd) containing twelve atoms per unit cell with lattice parameters a =3.784Å and c =9.514Å [43]. According to the factor group analysis, the six Raman active modes of anatase have the irreducible representation as A 1g +2B 1g +3E g. The Raman scattering peaks appearing at 144, 197, 397, 514, 639 are identified as E g, E g, B 1g, A 1g/B 1g and E g vibration modes of anatase phase [44]. The main peak positioned at 144cm−1 due to TiO symmetric stretching for anatase was observed for all the catalysts. Raman mode of V2O5 shown in Fig. 4, exhibits bands at 143, 198, 286, 306, 406, 483, 526, 702 and 996cm−1, which are characteristic modes of V2O5 [45]. The intensity of Raman peaks of S-TiO2(x) and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) are quite different from TiO2, showing the band broadening with decrease in intensity because of the presence of dopants on the surface of TiO2. The slight shift observed in Raman band position is shown in Fig. 4b and Table 3. The observed shift of 144cm−1 E g mode to 145.3cm−1 for S-TiO2(x) and to 147.3cm−1 for V2O5/S-TiO2(x), may plausibly be regarded as the result of modification in the force constants of surface TiOTi lattice structure by the added sulfur and vanadium dopant. This observation is in accordance with the XRD results (Fig. 2). This difference in Raman spectra of the sulfur and vanadium modified TiO2 catalysts can be attributed to numerous factors like phonon confinement, strain, non-homogenity of the size distribution, defects and non-stoichiometry, and particle size [46]. Noticeably, the main factors which affect the force constant and vibrational amplitudes of the nearest neighbor bond could be the effect of smaller particle size of TiO2, defects and non-stoichiometry [47]. The observed decrease in intensity and shift emphasize the breaking of symmetry due to the interaction of sulfur and V2O5 species on the surface of TiO2 lattice. The intensity of Raman peaks is also well correlated with the degree of crystallinity. It is also revealed from Fig. 4 that the degree of crystallization of S-TiO2(x) and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) is lower than that of pure TiO2. Raman spectroscopy was also used to identify the presence of other microcrystalline phase such as rutile or brookite. The absence of Raman peak at 442cm−1 identified as E g mode of rutile, confirms that all the catalysts contains only anatase phase and is also consistent with the XRD data (Fig. 2 and Table 1). Further, Raman bands at 996cm−1 due to V2O5 was not observed in the V2O5/S-TiO2(x) catalysts, which is again a confirmation for the fine dispersion of V2O5 on the TiO2 and S-TiO2 surface as observed from TEM (Fig. 3a (inset)). Fig. 5 shows the FTIR spectra of TiO2, S-TiO2(x), V2O5 and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) catalysts. The broad band observed in the region around 3200–3500cm−1 and a sharp band in the region around 1500–1650cm−1 is due to the stretching and bending vibrations of OH group, respectively. The bending mode of vibration of TiOTi observed around 420–650cm−1 confirms the formation of anatase TiO2. The band at 1016 due to VO (vanadyl oxygen) stretching mode of vibration and the bands at 844 and 580cm−1 are due to OVO stretching modes are observed for pure V2O5. The presence of bands around 1000–1030cm−1 represents the OVO stretching vibration and the band around 800–830cm−1 due to TiOV linkage [37] was observed for V2O5/TiO2 and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites. Further, the absence of bands in the region around 1100–1230cm−1, characteristic of chemisorbed sulfate groups, confirms the absence of sulfate species on the surface of the catalyst. The textural properties of S-TiO2(x) nanocatalysts and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites were obtained from N2 adsorption desorption analysis and are shown in Fig. 6 . S-TiO2(x) nanocatalysts (Fig. 6a) displayed a type IV adsorption isotherm according to the IUPAC, indicating the presence of mesopores [48]. The curve exhibited a H2 type hysteresis loop at relative pressure P/P 0 =0.5–0.9, which is a characteristic of materials with cage-like structures with cylindrical pore geometry connected by smaller openings (ink-bottle effect) and high degree of pore size uniformity [48]. The presence of these mesopores allows rapid diffusion of various reactants and products during photocatalytic reaction and enhances the rate of photocatalytic reaction. Furthermore, some small crystalline particles led to the interparticle pores, as indicated in the capillary condensation step at P/P 0 >0.98. However, the isotherm of V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites (Fig. 6b) shows type III isotherm indicating the formation of micropores [49]. This is due to the narrowing of pores caused by the addition of vanadium and thus rendering the microporosity. The absence of hysteresis loop further confirms the presence of microporosity. Table 1 lists the specific surface area (S BET), pore volume (V P) and pore diameter (D P) measured from BET linear plot and from BJH desorption branch. Considering the density of anatase (3.9g/cm3) and assuming the particles to be spherical, the average particle size calculated from the surface area correspond to particles with a mean diameter of 24, 30–60 and 60–93nm for TiO2, S-TiO2(x) and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) respectively. The average particle size was found to be larger than the crystallite size determined by XRD, suggesting the formation of nanoagglomerates in the crystallites of anatase [39]. The chemical states of the dopants and its atomic concentration in the TiO2 lattice were determined from the XPS spectral results. A typical XPS survey spectra of TiO2, S-TiO2(4), V2O5/TiO2, V2O5/S-TiO2(4) and V2O5 are shown in Fig. 7 . Distinct photoelectron peaks are seen for oxygen, titanium, sulfur and vanadium on the characteristic stepwise background; auger peaks were also observed in all the catalysts. The C 1s peak observed for all the catalyst is due to the deposition of adventitious hydrocarbon on the sample surface from the oil diffusion pumps evacuating the analysis chamber [48]. It can be observed that the intensity of the O 1s and Ti 2p peaks get reduced due to the presence of TiOS and V2O5 species on the surface of TiO2. This proves the fact that the added dopant atoms bring about the slight distortion of the TiO2 lattice as evident from the lattice parameter (Table 1). The high resolution XPS spectra of different elements such as Ti 2p, O 1s, S 2p and V 2p present in TiO2, S-TiO2(4), V2O5/TiO2, V2O5/S-TiO2(4) and V2O5 catalysts are presented in Fig. 8 . Spin-orbit coupling of 2p orbitals in titanium, vanadium and sulfur gives rise to two components 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 respectively. The exact binding energy values of the main XPS peaks and the corresponding energy difference (ΔE) values are given in Table 2 . Ti 2p spectrum of the TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 8a) does not show any additional peak except for Ti4+ 2p3/2 and Ti4+ 2p1/2 located at 458.6 and 464.2eV respectively. However, the Ti 2p spectrum of S-TiO2(4) catalyst (Fig. 8b) after curve fitting shows two additional peaks located at 459.1 and 465.4eV ascribed to Ti3+ 2p3/2 and Ti3+ 2p1/2 could be identified, suggesting the presence of Ti3+ species. Obviously, a binding energy shift of 1.1eV was observed for Ti4+ ion, characteristic of the formation of Ti3+ defects. The larger shifts of 3.1 or 4.1eV that is usually associated with Ti2+ or Ti0 states, respectively, was not observed [50]. Hence, it is concluded that the dopant (sulfur) induces defect structure (oxygen vacancy) resulting in the formation of Ti3+ species. It is worth noting that not only the presence of sulfur doping, but also the presence of Ti3+ affects the visible-light absorption, as evident from the DRUV–vis spectra (Fig. 1). The Ti 2p spectrum of V2O5/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 8c) also does not show any additional peak corresponding to Ti3+ species formation as well as the shift in binding energy by the addition of vanadium. However, the Ti 2p spectra of V2O5/S-TiO2(4) catalyst (Fig. 8d) after curve fitting also showed two additional peaks similar to the one observed for S-TiO2(4) catalyst, located at 461.0 and 466.4eV ascribed to Ti3+ 2p3/2 and Ti3+ 2p1/2, respectively. A binding energy shift of 1.0eV was also observed for Ti4+ ion confirming the presence of Ti3+ ion. However, it is observed that the formation of Ti3+ species increased by the addition of V2O5, due to the sharing of surface oxygen atom present in the TiO2 lattice with that of vanadium. The O 1s core level peak located at 529.8eV for TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 8a) is also found to be symmetric as observed for Ti 2p confirms the presence of only one type of oxygen atom. The O 1s peak of S-TiO2(4) catalyst (Fig. 8b) is also found to be asymmetric after curve fitting, besides the main peak of O 1s located at 528.8eV corresponding to lattice oxygen of TiO2. Two shoulder peaks at higher binding energies were observed at 530.2eV and 531.9eV. The peak at 530.2eV, may be attributed to the oxygen bound to sulfur atom present in the Ti–O–S species in the surface and the other peak at 531.9eV may be attributed to the surface species such as TiOH resulting from the reaction of chemisorbed water or/and oxygen molecules with Ti3+ on the surface [51]. However, the O 1s peak of V2O5/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 8c) shows two different peaks at 529.4 and 530.1eV. The peak at 529.4eV corresponds to lattice oxygen of TiO2 and the peak at 530.1eV corresponds to the V2O5 oxygen atom. The increase in peak intensity of 530.1eV peak indicates the presence of more number of V2O5 on the surface of TiO2. V2O5/S-TiO2(4) catalysts show three peaks at 530.8, 532.1 and 533.7eV corresponding to three different oxygen atoms. The peak at 530.8eV corresponds to both the lattice oxygen of TiO2 as well as the V2O5 oxygen atom, the peak at 532.1eV corresponds to the TiOS species in the surface, and the peak at 533.7eV corresponds to the surface TiOH species. The shift in 2.1eV is observed for the TiOS and TiOH species due to the interaction with vanadium. The O 1s peak of V2O5 catalyst (Fig. 8e) shows one peak at 530.1eV corresponding to V2O5 oxygen atom. It can be observed that S 2p broad peak of S-TiO2(4) catalyst (Fig. 8b) can be deconvoluted to four peaks, in which the two main peaks at 167.4eV and 169.5eV are the characteristics of S4+ and S6+, respectively [14] that proves the substitution of Ti4+. Further, the presence of sulfur atom on the surface of TiO2 lattice is confirmed. However, the V2O5/S-TiO2(4) catalyst (Fig. 8d) shows only one main peak at 170.0eV corresponding to the S6+ ion. This shows that the addition of V2O5 to S-TiO2(x) catalysts, favors the formation of TiOS species more on the surface than at the bulk. The absence of peak at 164.8eV in both S-TiO2(4) and V2O5/TiO2 catalysts confirms that there is no TiS bond formation (Fig. 8b and d). The binding energy values of V 2p 3/2 were observed at 516.8eV, 517.6eV and 516.8eV for V2O5/TiO2, V2O5/S-TiO2(4) and V2O5 catalysts, respectively (Fig. 8c, d (inset) and e). The binding energy value in the region 516–517eV corresponds to V5+ in V2O5 according to the literature reports [52]. This broad XPS peak indicates the dispersion of vanadium oxide over the TiO2 and S-TiO2(4) in V2O5/TiO2 and V2O5/S-TiO2(4) catalysts. The intensity of the V 2p peaks is small compared to the oxygen peak because of the small amount of vanadium. The observed small shift in O 1s, Ti 2p, S 2p and V 2p binding energy values is mainly due to the change in electronic environment around these atoms. The compositional analysis was performed to know the exact amount of sulfur and vanadium present in the catalysts. The exact amount of sulfur present in the catalysts was obtained by the elemental analyzer (CHNS Analyzer). The atomic % of sulfur present was found to be 1.9at.% in S-TiO2(2), 3.8at.% in S-TiO2(4) and 4.1at.% in S-TiO2(6) catalysts. The further decrease in atomic % of sulfur is also observed for V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites. The atomic % of sulfur present in the nanocomposites was found to be 0.8, 1.1 and 1.4at.% for V2O5/S-TiO2(2), V2O5/S-TiO2(4) and V2O5/S-TiO2(6), respectively. The exact amount of V2O5 present in the catalyst was estimated to be in the range of 2.79 to 2.87wt.% as obtained from the ICP–OES analysis (Table 3 ). It is found that the amount of V2O5 present is the same as the amount taken, but the amount of sulfur is found to be less. 3.2 Photocatalytic activity The photocatalytic activity of the synthesized catalysts was estimated by the photocatalytic active species OH radical generation under visible light irradiation. It has been reported that the OH radical reacts with terephthalic acid in basic solution and generates 2-hydroxy terephthalic acid, which emits a unique fluorescence signal with the peak at 426nm [40]. Fig. 9a shows the fluorescence spectra of V2O5/S-TiO2(4) catalyst recorded at different interval of irradiation time. The dependence of fluorescence intensity on the irradiation time of all the catalysts is shown in Fig. 9b. The observed linear relationship between the fluorescence intensity and the time clearly reveals the stability of the synthesized catalyst. The number of photocatalytically active OH radicals generated by the catalysts directly depends on the visible-light absorption of the catalyst. In order to obtain the real photodegradation rate, the decrease in MB concentration due to adsorption has been carefully measured on S-TiO2(x) and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) catalysts were shown in Fig. 10 and found that most of the adsorption of MB takes place within 30min. The amount of MB adsorbed at 30min on various catalysts is tabulated in Table 3. From Fig. 11 , it can be observed that all the reactions were found to follow a pseudo-first-order kinetics. Illumination in the absence of catalyst and the reaction in dark with various catalysts do not facilitate the degradation of MB. The apparent rate constant, k is calculated from the linear fitting on ln(C 0/C t ) versus reaction time and shown in Fig. 12 . It can be seen from the figure that the rate of photocatalytic degradation of MB under visible light is found to be very low on pure TiO2. This is due to the fact that pure TiO2 has large band gap energy of about 3.1eV. The complete degradation of MB was achieved within 6h on all the catalysts (Table 3). The doping of non-metals into TiO2 plays an important role in the visible-light photocatalytic activity. In case of S-TiO2(x) catalysts, the apparent rate constant was found to increase with increase in sulfur content up to 4 mole ratio and further increase in sulfur content slightly decreased the rate constant (Fig. 12). There is no significant band gap narrowing observed for S-TiO2(2) catalyst with low sulfur content, as evident from Fig. 1 and hence, decrease in photocatalytic rate was observed. However, by increasing the sulfur content, a significant increase in visible light absorption was observed for S-TiO2(4) catalyst and is reflected in the increased photocatalytic activity. With increase in sulfur doping, decrease in particle size is observed (Table 1), which reflected in the increase in surface area. Hence, the number of molecules adsorbed gets increase and seems to enhance the photocatalytic activity. In addition to bandgap narrowing, the size dependent properties of the S-TiO2(4) also play a role in enhancing the photocatalytic activity. Even though, the sulfur content is high and particle size is small in S-TiO2(6) catalyst, no significant change in visible light absorption was observed. It also showed similar absorption as that of S-TiO2(4) catalyst. The observed decrease in photocatalytic activity of S-TiO2(6) catalyst implies that the sulfur atom may get diffused into the bulk and thereby acts as the trap for charge carriers. Furthermore, the amorphous nature of S-TiO2(6) catalyst (Fig. 2) reflected in decrease in surface area contributes to the decrease in photocatalytic activity. It can be observed from Fig. 12 that the photocatalytic activity of S-TiO2(x) and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) under visible light irradiation was found to be more than that of Aeroxide P25, with the exception of TiO2 and S-TiO2(2). This is due to the increase in visible-light absorption and the observed red shift in absorption edge for S-TiO2(x) and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocatalysts (Fig. 1). This further implies that the V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites which have a large red shift in absorption can be easily activated by visible-light to generate more number of photoinduced electrons and holes. This resulted in the generation of more number of reactive OH radicals that can take part in the reaction. Hence, the band-gap narrowing observed in S-TiO2(x) and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) (Table 1) is responsible for the enhanced visible-light photocatalytic activity. The presence of Ti3+ defect site (as evident from XPS analysis Fig. 8b and d) in S-TiO2(4) and V2O5/S-TiO2(4) catalysts further enhances the adsorption of water to produce more number of hydroxyl and peroxide reactive species, which resulted in enhanced photocatalytic activity. A higher rate constant (18×10−3 min−1) for visible light photocatalytic activity of V2O5/S-TiO2(4) compared with that of TiO2 and S-TiO2(4) catalysts, suggests that V2O5/S-TiO2(x) catalyst is very efficient to generate more number of reactive OH radical species (Fig. 9b) under visible light irradiation and responsible for the enhanced photocatalytic activity. The steps involved in the process of MB degradation can be proposed as: (1) V2O5/S-TiO2(x)+ hυ →V2O5/S-TiO2(x)(e− +h+) (2) e− +O2 →O2 − +H+ →HO2 (3) h+ + − OH→ OH (4) HO2 +H+ +e− →H2O2 + hυ →2OH (5) HO2 + OH→O2 +H2O (6) MB+ hυ →MB* (7) O2 − +HO2 + OH+MB*→Intermediates→EndProducts (8) Catalyst+ hυ +O2 − +HO2 + OH+MB*→CO2 +H2O+SO4 2− +NO3 − +Cl− +NH4 + The catalysts on irradiation with light generates e−/h+ pairs, which reacts with the oxygen and hydroxyl ion to produce super oxide radical (O2 −) and hydroxyl radical (OH), respectively (Steps 1–3). The dissolved oxygen in the solution plays an important role by trapping the conduction band electrons forming superoxide ions (O2 −) and thus preventing the electron–hole recombination. Hence, oxygen was found to be essential for semiconductor photocatalytic degradation of organic compounds. However, experiments were carried out in the absence of oxygen (nitrogen bubbling) for V2O5/S-TiO2(4) catalyst. The decrease in rate constant was observed for the degradation of MB in the absence of oxygen (Fig. 13 ). The super oxide radical further reacts with the proton and yields hyperoxyl radical, HO2 (Step 2). The hyperoxyl radical further generates more number of reactive OH radicals as shown in Step 4. The super oxide radical (O2 −) and hydroxyl radical (OH) plays an important role in the photocatalytic reaction due to their strong oxidizing properties. Wong and Chu reported that the generation of hyperoxyl radical (Step 2) results in the decrease of degradation rate [54], which may be due to the time taken for the formation of OH radical from the hyperoxyl radical as shown in Step 4 and also due to the formation of inactive species such as oxygen and water as shown in Step 5. However, Stylidi et al. reported that the repeated attack of these species (OH, O2 − and HO2 ) results in the formation of carbon dioxide and other end products [55]. Simultaneously, MB shows an absorption in the visible region gets excited to singlet or triplet states upon irradiation, due to the absorbing properties of the dye (Step 6). The excited MB molecule (MB*) injects an electron into the CB of the catalysts, where the electrons are scavenged by the molecular oxygen. The scavenging of electrons reduces the electron hole recombination and the system acts as a dye sensitized system to induce visible light activity [56]. The dye sensitization effect is reduced by the degradation of adsorbed MB due to the attack of reactive species formed on the surface of the catalyst. Fig. 14 shows the MB degradation profile for V2O5/S-TiO2(4) catalysts under optimized conditions. The figure clearly shows the oxidative degradation route of MB. Typically MB shows absorption around 264, 291 and 664nm, corresponding to benzene rings and heteropolyaromatic rings, respectively. The observed decrease in absorbance and the shift in 664nm peak toward the blue region (hypsochromic effect) clearly prove the stepwise removal of the auxochromes (methyl or methylamine). Examination of the spectral variation in Fig. 14 suggests that MB was N-demethylated in a stepwise manner as reported in the literature [53]. A similar trend in degradation profile was observed for all the catalysts. The weak electron donor substituent (methyl group) present in the MB, facilitates the attack of OH radicals or h+ in the demethylation process, likely to be a major step in the oxidative degradation of MB [53]. The removal of methyl groups results in the formation of various intermediates with different absorption behavior. The formation of following intermediates such as azure B (λ max – 648–655nm), azure A (λ max – 620–634nm), azure C (λ max – 608–612nm) and thionine or phenothiazine (λ max – 602nm) is clearly evidenced from the shift in absorption band [53]. The change in λ max (664nm peak) observed (Δλ) at 240min is calculated for all the catalysts and are tabulated in Table 3. The intensities of the bands at 264 and 292nm are also found to decrease significantly with irradiation time and no new bands were observed. This implies that there is complete degradation of the intermediates formed (Fig. 14). Further, to confirm the MB degradation, TOC analysis was performed and the plot of [TOC] t /[TOC]0 as a function of time (min) is shown in Fig. 15 . After 120min (2h), the solution turned colorless and was accompanied by decrease in TOC content for V2O5/S-TiO2(4), S-TiO2(4), V2O5/S-TiO2(6), V2O5/TiO2 and S-TiO2(6) catalysts. However, the decrease in TOC content and the complete decolorization for V2O5/S-TiO2(2) catalysts was observed only after 240min (4h). The catalysts such as TiO2, S-TiO2(2) and Aeroxide P25 show similar trend in TOC removal and complete decolorization was observed at around 360–420min (6–7h). Pure V2O5 does not decolorize MB completely or the removal of TOC even after 12h of the reaction. After the complete degradation of MB, the catalysts were separated by centrifugation and washed repeatedly with water for several time to remove the adsorbed molecules. The separated catalysts were dried at 373K for 2h and reused. The photocatalytic activities of the reused catalysts were tested under similar conditions and the results are tabulated in Table 4 . Table 4 shows the comparison of compositional analysis and photocatalytic activity of fresh and reused catalysts: TiO2, S-TiO2(4), V2O5, V2O5/TiO2, and V2O5/S-TiO2(4). It is found that there is a reduction in the sulfur content of the used S-TiO2(4) catalyst showing that the sulfur is not tightly bound to TiO2 which is reflected in the decrease in activity. However, in the case of used V2O5/S-TiO2(4) nanocomposites there is not much of sulfur loss compared with that of fresh catalyst. The results show that the sulfur atom gets stabilized on the surface of S-TiO2(4) by the presence of V2O5. In the present work, the band gap energy diagram has been proposed for S-TiO2 and V2O5/TiO2 from the UV–vis spectral results (Fig. 1) and shown in Fig. 16 . The conduction band edge ( E CB 0 ) of a semiconductor at the PHzpc is predicted by the equation: E CB 0 = χ − E c − 1 / 2 E g , where, χ is the absolute electronegativity (TiO2 – 5.8, V2O5 – 6.10 and for S-TiO2 it is unknown), E c is the energy of free electrons on the hydrogen scale (4.5eV) and E g the band gap energy (obtained from the UV data) [57]. By considering, the band edge positions of conduction band (CB) and valence band (VB) of TiO2 and V2O5 reported by Wang et al. [58], the positions of S-TiO2 were proposed. As reported by Sathish et al. [59], the contribution of S orbital in the CB of TiO2 is more than in the VB (9.16% for CB and 2.36% for VB). Hence, the position of conduction band of S-TiO2 catalyst has been determined based on the calculated VB position of undoped TiO2 and is clearly seen in Fig. 16. The contact between two different semiconductors TiO2 and V2O5 with different energy levels generally involves a redistribution of electric charges. This redistribution causes the shift in band edge positions (Fig. 16b). This is known as the Fermi level alignment. This induces the equal distribution of electrons and holes to locate on the TiO2 and V2O5 species at the V2O5/TiO2 interface. It indicates that the photogenerated electrons and holes are well separated and reduces the charge recombination process [59]. The increase in the charge separation of the photogenerated electrons and holes allows both photogenerated electrons and holes to participate in the overall photocatalytic reaction. In case of V2O5/S-TiO2 system, the addition of sulfur decreases the band edge of CB and further increases the flow of charged species. Hence, the migration of charge carriers between S-TiO2 and V2O5 resulted in the charge separation and increased the number of e−/h+ pairs on the surface. This produces more number of photogenerated reactive OH radical species and resulted in enhanced visible-light photocatalytic activity of V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites. 4 Conclusion S-TiO2(x) nanocatalysts with varied S/Ti molar ratio were prepared by sol–gel method and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites were prepared by wet impregnation method. The change in optical properties of TiO2 by the incorporation of S atom into the TiO2 lattice and by the addition of V2O5 species is confirmed from the DRUV–vis spectral studies. The XPS studies further confirms the change in electronic property and the band gap narrowing due to mixing of valence band of the dopant atoms with the valence band of TiO2. The presence of S as dopant in S-TiO2 appears to be beneficial for enhancing the visible-light photocatalytic activity of the catalysts. It is concluded from the study on the effect of S/Ti molar ratio a certain amount of sulfur (S/Ti=4) is essential for enhancing the visible-light photocatalytic activity. The addition of V2O5 to S-TiO2(x) facilitates the formation of nanocomposites, which enhances considerably the visible-light photocatalytic degradation of MB compared to TiO2 and S-TiO2(x) under the experimental conditions studied. The enhanced visible-light photocatalytic activity is mainly due to the efficient visible-light absorption of V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites around 450–550nm. The efficient charge separation has increased the number of photogenerated reactive OH radical species due to the migration of charge carriers between S-TiO2 and V2O5, as evident from the formation of 2-hydroxyterephthalic acid. Thus, it is concluded from the results that V2O5/S-TiO2 nanocomposite can be used as an efficient visible-light active photocatalyst under the experimental conditions. coredata.dc:description: Diverse approaches are being made in search of a visible-light active TiO2 photocatalysts. In this study, S-TiO2(x) nanocatalysts with x =2, 4 and 6 (x =S/Ti molar ratio) were synthesized by sol–gel method and V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites by wet impregnation method using ammonium metavanadate as a source of vanadium. The synthesized catalysts were characterized by diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, N2 adsorption desorption studies, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and high resolution transmission electron microscopy techniques. The photogenerated reactive species OH radical estimated from photoluminescence spectra was directly correlated to the visible-light absorption of the catalyst. The photocatalytic activities of all the synthesized catalysts were evaluated for the degradation of MB under visible light irradiation. The excellent stability of V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites has been revealed from the linear relationship between the fluorescence intensity and the time. The addition of sulfur and V2O5 to TiO2 has significantly enhanced the visible-light photocatalytic activity by modifying the optical and electronic properties of TiO2. The enhanced visible-light photocatalytic activity has been attributed to the efficient visible-light absorption of V2O5/S-TiO2(x) nanocomposites and efficient charge separation due to migration of charge carriers between S-TiO2 and V2O5.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced visible-light photocatalytic activity of V2O5/S-TiO2 nanocomposites
